editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

LONDINI. Typis J. G. & proſtant voenales apud Johannem Crook, ſub inſigni Navis, in Coemeterio Paulino, 1656.
EDOARDO AƲREOLO, EQUITI, OPTIMO VIRTUTIS, In peſsima aetate, EXEMPLARI, Bonarum literarum PATRONO ORNATISSIMO; Hanc perexiguam gratae ſuae mentis TESSERAM V. V.

div.head: Forms of ſpeaking.
The firſt Century.
div.p: I wiſh the ſame to you.

My father doth entreat you,
That you would pleaſe to dine with him.
That you would ſup with him.
I prethee excuſe me to him.
I will come, if I can poſſible.
I am very full of buſineſſe.
WHat hour is it? or what of the clock is it?
I did not tell the clock.
Set the ſalt on the board.
Bring water to waſh our hands.
The meat is upon the table.
The dinner is ſpoil'd with your ſtay.
Where would you have me to ſit?
Sit at the upper end of the table.
through Jeſus Chr: our Lord, Amen.
and for ever and ever, Amen.
from whom all good doth proceed
who livest and reigneſt world without end, Amen.
A health to you all all in beer.
Fill ſom beer, wine, that wee may drinke.
Will you not pleaſe to drink?
I will leave enough for you.
Set the other meat on the board.
Doe you not remember the Greeke Proverb,

Broile this
fiſh upon the gridiron.
fleſh upon the gridiron.
Take heed it be not burn'd.

Have a care to boil the egges—
ſoft.
hard.

div.head: Loquendi formulae, ſive Colloquia.
Centuria prima.
div.p:
Pater meus rogat te,
Ut apud ſe prandeas.
Ut ſis ejus conviva in coena.
Quaeſo te ut me excuſes apud illum.
Quid obſtat quò minus venire poſſis?
per Jeſum Chriſtū Dominum noſtrum, Amen.
à quo omne bononorum genus emanat,
qui vivis & regnas, in ſaecula ſaeculorum, Amen.
Abſcinde mihi aliquid de carne bovina.
Torre hunc piſcē, carnem in craticula.
Cave ut ova coquantur molliuſcula, duriuſcula.

div.head: 100. The ſecond Century.
div.p: Take heed you put it not out.

Bring me the apples
pears
cherries
wall-nuts
ſmall nuts.

Reach we the butter
cheeſe
bread
ſalt.
Lay more wood on the fire.

I invite you to
dinner to morrow
ſupper to morrow
You are onely to be condemned,
take this poor ſupper in good part.
that you would vouchſafe to come.

p.label: 20. Formes how we ought aske any thing of the Maſter.

div.p: I have ſome buſines to doe.
I muſt goe into the field.
I deſire it may be done with your liking.
I pray give mee leave to go forth,
LEt me goe out of the Schoole,
One ſtayes to speak with me
Pray give me leave to goe to him.
My Father bid me come home at foure.
That I may doe ſo, I beg your favour.
Therefore I pray let me goe home.
John deſires you would not be angry for his abſence.
I have loſt a Book yeſterday.
If any one have found it,
How ſhall I ſay in Greek?
I Pray ſet mee a copy of Greek Letters,
which I wrote for you a while ago?
I loſt it by my negligence.
Take heed you doe not loſe this too.
I pray make me a pen.
What kinde of pen doe you deſire?
MAke it for your own hand.
Set me how much I ſhall learne.

I have no inke,
knife,
penne,
money.
Why doe you come ſo late?
Our people call'd me up late.
I riſe late againſt my will.
I had left my book at home,
And was faine to to runne back to fetch it.
MY Mother ſent me of an errand.
My Mother would not let me come,
We had a Wedding at our houſe.
that he is not at School.
why you are not preſent at the Lectures.
I wil preſently come to School.
I have been careful Maſter to doe your commands.
He has been ſick in Bed three dayes.
His Father and Mother ſay he is gone into the Countrey.
His Father ſayes he had no buſineſſe,
Therefore he entreats you to whip him,
He is ſick of a Feaver.

div.head: 100. Centuria ſecunda.
div.p:
Appone poma
pyra
ceraſa
juglandes
nuces avellanas.

Porrige mihi butyrum
caſeum
panem
ſalem

In craftinum te ad
prandium voco.
coenam voco.
Tunc quidem manendum eſt mihi domi.
Id unum habes cur accuſandus ſis,
Ego agnoſco me tibi gratiā debere
Id, ut tuâ pace fiat, oro.
Quiſpiam me conventum expetit, prae foribus,
Liceat, mihi, pace tua, ad hunc exire.
Pater meus juſſit me domum redire horâ quartâ.
Id ut mihi liceat facere, oro.
Ideo quaeſo liceat mihi ire domum.
Johannes petit ſibi abſenti veniam dari.
Si quis fortè eum invenerit, mihi reſtituat.
DEſcribas quaeſo mihi figuras elementorum Graecorum,
quem ante paucos dies tibi praeſcripſi?
Quaeſo te ut praepares mihi pennā.

Non eſt mihi atramentum,
cultellus,
penna,
pecunia.
Et ex itinere domum recurri, ut afferrem.
quòd nunc non ſit in Schola.
Ideo oro, ut me abſentem excuſes.
ſtatim revertar ad vos in Scholam.
Decumbit in lecto jam tres dies.
Parentes dicunt ipſum peregrè profectum eſſe.
Pater dicit, ei nihil fuiſſe negotii,

div.head: 100. The third Century.
div.p: He will not let me write.
He put out his foot to give me a fall.
He pull'd me by the haires.
He will not let me goe by him.
He diſturbes me at my leſſon.
He thruſt me out of my place.
HE ſtruck me with his fiſt inkhorne.
He took me a boxe o'th eare.

He threw at me
his book,
a ſtone,
ſnow.
He cut me with a knife.
He put not off his Hat at you paſt by.
He does not obey his Parents.
Therefore he invents this againſt me.
I Did it againſt my will.
I will doe ſo no more.

I had no leiſure
to write,
to learne.
My buſineſs would not let me come.
I have ſomething to ſay to you.
I have a ſuite to you.
I will doe it, but upon this condition,
That you will doe as much for me,
How far muſt we ſay without book?
And I will heare you again.
It is better to offend by ſlow speaking,
You muſt truſt your memory, not books.

Give me a little of
your inke,
your paper.

Whoſe book is this?
mine,
Peters.
You have had it long enough.
Let me ſee it a little.
Be ſilent, and doe your buſineſſe.
That knowes, and ſees all things.
Will you contend with me in writing?
Let me in, open the door.
Are you in jeſt or earneſt?
What misfortune hath hapned to you?
What fault did you commit? None.
This is the common anſwer of Children,
when they deſerve to be whipt.
What is the quarrel amongst you?
Let us referre it to the Ʋſher.
Where is the book I lent you?

div.head: 100. Centuria tertia.
div.p:
Conjecit in me
librum,
lapidem,
nivem.

Non ſuit mihi otiū
ſcribendi,
diſcendi.
Satius eſt peccare tarditate in loquendo,

Da mihi paululū de
tuo atramento,
tua charta.

Cujus eſt liber?
meus,
Petri eſt.
Tace, & quae tibi mandato ſunt facito.
Placet tibi certare mecum in ſcribendo?
Referamus de hac controverſia ad ſubdoctorem.
Ubi eſt liber quem tibi commodadatò dederam?

div.head: 100. The fourth Century.
div.p: I remembred it not when I came from home.
I wil bring it without faile to day, to morrow.

It is my turne,
thine,
John's.
Put the Books in their place.
Why are you more melancholy then uſually?
My Maſter threatned to beat me.
At what houre muſt we come again?
John is gone out of the School.
What did you pay for this book?
I had it cheap, too deare.
No Man will ſell it cheaper.
The weather invites us to play.
We muſt not play without leave.
Some one is to be ſent,
that may get leave for us.
Let, Paul goe, he has a good tongue and is bold.
Let him goe that has a minde to't,
I had rather want then aske it.
Deare heart goe, and make us all bound to thee.
Your importunity ſhall prevaile upon me.
NO man is more fit to goe upon this meſſage.
Your Scholars deſire of your Clemency leave to play.
and let them returne in good time,
I have got leave, though with much adoe.
But we muſt beware we doe no harme.
We will conſider what to play at, when we come into the Field.
As ſoon as I kembed my haire,
waſhed my face, mouth, and hands,
and with my hands lifted up,
In what language doe you pray?
You doe well and vertuouſly in it.
Have a care you neglect not this duty.

I will have a diligent
care, if it pleaſe God.
to give an account of your Study?
Can you ſay your leſſon without book?
that you may tell me when I ſay wrong.
You have miſt once, twice, thrice, foure times,
I thought I could ſay excellent well.
when my memory is not confirm'd.
He is happy that has a good memory.
Nay, I am very much at leiſure.
You are come in the very nick.
I would be loath to trouble you.

div.head: 100. Centuria quarta.
div.p: Non venit mihi in mentem cùm domo exirem.
Ad quotam horam juſſi ſumus redire?
Eat Paulus, nam bene linguax eſt & audax.
I, quaeſo, magnam à nobis initurus gratiam.
Quandoquidem id tantopere contenditis, provinciam accipiam.
NEmo ad hanc legationem magis idoncus.
Diſcipuli tui orant humanitatem tuam ludendi veniam.
De luſus genere in campo conſultabimus.
Cura ut hanc officii tui partem nunquam negligas.
Sed tu attentè an ſculta me,
cùm memoria non ſatis confirmata eſt.
Foelix qui memoriâ bonâ praeditus eſt.
Sed quomodo ſe res habent tuae?
Fartaſſis te occupatum ſeriis negotiis interpello.
ſi parum in tempore te interpellarim.

div.head: 100. The fifth Century.
div.p: My eare did tingle as I came ſtrangely.
And therefore I thinke there was no good spoken of me.
And I have in my net what I hunted for.
whom I am to marry the next day after to morrow.
We wiſh you joy of her,
for ſhe is not onely beautifull,
and inſtructed to be a good houſewife.
grace my wedding with your preſence.
This man wil break the doors I think.
You bring a thing but little worth.
But my Father paid dear for me.
I believe he paid more for you,
Go your ſelf rather, and aske
whether he will be at home or no.
Thou impudence! doe not I heare thee ſpeak to me?
I gave beliefe to your Maid lately, that you were not at home,
ANd will not you give credit to my ſelfe?
You returne ſuch as I gave you.
But you live like a fiſh in the ſhell.
I have ſomething to doe at home.
this weather would keep me within doors a few dayes.
BƲt now it is a cleer day,
If you have a mind to a walk,
You ſit too cloſe to your booke.
You conſume your ſelf with immoderate ſtudy.
I had rather languiſh with ſtudy, then love.
Was not this a pleaſant walk?
Truly I tooke much delight in it.
I wiſh you very much happineſs.
I Wiſh you twice as much.
What doe you talke to your ſelfe?
Truly I talke with a moſt pleaſant companion.
WE cannot have too much learning.
But a moderation is beſt in all things
Nothing is ſweet, that is perpetuall.
You have not left your jeering.
I Pray take my buſineſſe to your speciall care.
that you would mind this buſineſs.
I will doe it for you,
but Ile promiſe you, neither faith nor care ſhall be wanting.
but I will make good in action,
WHat happened, that you have not ſeen us all this while?
I had a good minde to't,

upon condition you
uſe it not.
Your excuſe is more juſt then I deſire.

div.head: 100. Centuria quinta.
div.p: Mirè huc venienti mihi tinniebat auris.
Unde conjicio nihil magnificè de me fuiſſe dictum.
Et intra caſſes meos eſt praeda, quā venabar.
& ad curanda negotia domeſtica, benè inſtituta.
Tu certè rem haud magni pretii huc attuliſti.
Credo eum ſumptus majores in te feciſſe,
Nuper ancillae tuae credidi, te non eſſe domi,
ET tu non credis mihi ipſi?
Sed tu mihi videris cochleae vitam agere.
haec aura me dies aliquot à publico cohibuiſſet.
Ego quidem eâ vehementer delectatus ſum.
COnduplicatū tibi opto quicquid optas mihi.
QUaeſo ut haec res tibi cordi ſit.
ut hoc negotium tibi curae ſit.
illud poll ceor, mihi nec fidem, nec ſtudium defuturum.
QUid accidit, quòd tamdiu nos non inviſeris?
ſed non data eſt mihi facultas.
Excuſatio tua juſtior eſt quàm vellem.
ſi quidem morbus fuit in cauſa.

div.head: 100. The ſixt Century.
div.p: THe matter hath ſucceedde more happily then I expected.
I obtained more then I had confidence to aske.
It fell out as I would have it.
I ſhall thank you as long as I live.
I can hardly thank you ſufficiently,
then that you ſhould thanke me, or I you,
He that doth good for a friend,
He that deſerves wel from a friend,
but puts it out to uſe.
I Congratulate your returne into your Countrey.
I am glad to ſee you alive.
You had no beard when you went,
you are come back with a buſh.
I rejoyce for your ſake, and our ſelves,
that you come home ſafe and ſound.
why theſe wrinckles in your forehead?
My Body is like my Fortune.
Though fortune never ſmil'd upon me much,
ſhe was never more then now my enemy.
I have loſt all my money.
I make no queſtion, but you pray'd heartily.
He that knowes not how to pray, let him goe to ſea.
I Find it true by experience.
Better loſe our money then our life.
Learning and Vertue are the ſafest riches,
which can neither be taken away,
but in the meane time I have the ſmart.
But whither are you bound now?
A footman carries no great weight.
I will not burden you much.
That you would commend me to all my friends.
If you load me but with compliments,
And that you may not doe it for nothing,
I pray God keep you company.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.p: SIr, I having ſtudied ſome years already
have been taught faithfully by you.
But now it hath pleaſed my Parents,
that I ſhould goe to ſome Ʋniverſity,
that I may improve my Learning,
and ſerve God more profitably in ſome Calling.
Wherefore I moſt humbly thanke you,
for the many benefits you have conferred upon me,
and I promiſe, that I will not onely bear them in memory,

div.p: BƲt publiſh them alſo to all good men,
with a gratefull minde and tongue.

sp.speaker: Maſter.
sp.p: This expreſſion of your modeſty and gratitude,
which you have declared in language,
And I would to God, there were more like you
and looſe garbe of young men,
who would imitate your diligence in your learning,
But I not only with a good will

div.p: BƲt alſo aske of God in my prayers,
that he guide and direct you hereafter;
that as you have made a faire beginning,
and not ſuffer your ſelfe to be tainted with the examples of bad men,
whereof there is too great a plenty every where:
That in ſhort time you be a ſervant to the Church and State,
an honour to friends and Countrey,
and a pleaſure and comfort to your friends.

div.head: 100. Centuria ſexta.
div.p: Plus impetravi quā auſus fuiſſem optare.
Gratiam tibi habiturus ſum, quoad vivam maximam.
quae tu plurima in me contuliſti.
quàm ut tu mihi gratias deberes, vel ego tìbi,
Si ex animo probas officium in te meum,
GRatulor tibi de reditu in patriam.
quòd vivus & valens nobis ſis reſtitutus.
Qualis fortuna, talis eſt corporis habitus.
Etſi nullo ferè tempore fortuna mihi favit,
tamen nunquam mihi magis quàm nunc adverſa eſt.
Non dubium eſt quin diligenter oraveris.
Bene eſt quòd vivus nobi enataſti.
Melius eſt pecuniae, quàm vitae jacturam facere.
Ut omnes familiares meos amanter ſalutes.
Si nihil aliud ſarcicinae imponis prae ter ſalutationes,
precor ut deus tibi comes itineris ſit.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.p: EGo aliquot jam annos bonis literis operam navans
ut me hinc ad Academiam aliquam me conferam,
ubi poſſim ampliorem ingenii cultum capere,
& deo in functione aliquâ honeſtâ utiliùs ſervire.
pro pluribus in me tuis beneficiis,
& polliceor me illa non ſolùm perpetuò meminiſſe,

div.p: SEd etiam apud omnes bonos praedicare,

sp.speaker: Ludimagiſter.
sp.p: qui tuam diligentiam imitarentur in diſcendis literis,

div.p: nec te corrumpi ſinas pravorum hominum exemplis,

quorum ubi
que magna eſt copia:
Ut paulò poſt emolumento ſis eccleſiae & reipublicae,

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You ſhould rather bid me inspect your Ʋrine.
Doe you take me for a Phyſitian?
I doe not enquire whether your body be in health, for your face speaks that well.
But how you pleaſe your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: Truly my body is ſound, but my mind is not well.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Truly he is not right, that is ſick thereabout.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p:
The matter is ſo with me,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
my body is well, but my purſe is ſick.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your Mother will eaſily cure that diſeaſe.
But how have you done all this while?

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: Sometimes well, & ſometimes ill, according to the condition of humane affaires.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Have you conſtantly enjoyed your health?

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: By Gods mercy, I have continued healthfull.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: God grant it may be ſo ſtill.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: Nothing but that I could not enjoy your ſociety.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Non rogo, an vales corpore, nam facies ipſa loquitur te bene valere.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Corpus quidē bellè habet, ſed animo malè eſt.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Non valet quidem, qui iſta parte laborat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sic res habēt meae,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
corpus valet, ſed aegrotat crumena.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dei beneficio, ego ſemper belliſſimè habui.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Faxit deus, ut iſtud ſit perpetuum.
Sed nihil interim tibi moleſtiae fuit?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nihil niſi quòd non licuit frui veſtra conſuetudine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not ſo well, as I could wiſh.
I am as it pleaſes God.
As they uſe to be, that have to doe with Phiſitians.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: But you muſt be of good courage.
You muſt ſhew your ſelfe a man.
Behave your ſelfe valiantly againſt your diſeaſe.
A good confidence helps in a bad matter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know not, and therefore it is more dangerous with me.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: To know the diſeaſe, is the firſt degree to health.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: They all agree in this, that I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: How long have you been ſick?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I have been ſick theſe ten monthes.
A whole yeare I have been ſick.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: If I may be worthy to counſell you, you muſt have a care, that the diſeaſe be not familiar.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What kinde of Feaver is it?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I thinke it be ſome new kinde of Feaver, as now a dayes new diſeaſes ariſe, not known before.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: There were too many of the old.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So it pleaſeth God, to puniſh new ſins with new diſeaſes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What day does your fit returne?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: even every day, oftner then Euripus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: How did you come by this infirmity?
How do you ſuspect you took it?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You were not wont to be ſo ſuperſtitious, to ſterve your ſelfe with faſting.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
It was not conſcience
but want.
I thinke it came of a cold.
This rawneſſe of my ſtomach came as I ſuppoſe, from raw Apples.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Rather from too much, or unſeaſonable ſtudy, you have got this miſchiefe, or drinking too much.
But why doe you not conſult a Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am afraid he will ſooner enlarge my diſeaſe than cure it.
I feare he may give me poyſon in ſtead of a remedy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Therefore you muſt make choice of one, whom you may ſafely trust.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
If I muſt dye,
I had rather dye once, then be maſſacred by ſo many Medicines.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Provide then to be your owne Phyſitian.
If you have no confidence in a humane Phyſitian, I pray God ſupply your Phyſitians place.
Therefore aske of God the benefit of health.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know not whether it be a benefit or no.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Is it not a benefit to be freed from a diſeaſe?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: It is ſometimes more happineſſe to dye.
But I entreat of God, onely what may be best.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
You act the Chriſtian
Philoſopher: for when we aske good things of God, neceſſary for this life, we muſt alwaies adde, Our Lord if thou pleaſe.
But ſpirituall and eternall things are to be asked of God without any condidition.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And farewell you till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ut illi ſolent, quibus cum medicis res eſt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Forti infractóque animo eſto contra morbum.
Multum juvat animus in re malâ bonus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Noviſſe morbum, primus ad ſanitatem gradus eſt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In hoc conſentiunt omnes, me miſerum eſſe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Quantū temporis eſt quòd te hoc malum corripuit?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ego cenſeo, admittendum eſſe, ne morbus fiat familiaris.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Opinor novam eſſe febris ſpeciem, ut nunc novi ſubinde morbi exoriuntur, antehac incogniti.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ita viſum eſt deo, nova peccata punire novis morbis.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Unde ſuſpicaris hoc eſſe collectum mali.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Non ſoles uſque adeò eſſe ſuperſtitioſus, ut te jejunio maceres.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Haec ſtomachi cruditas contracta eſt, ut opinor, è crudis malis.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ex immodico potiùs aut intempeſtivo ſtudio, conciliaris tibi hoc mali, aut potatione largiori.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Timeo nè citiùs augeat morbum quàm curet.
Timeo ne venenum det pro remedio.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Deligendus eſt igitur, cui tuto fidas.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Si moriendum eſt,
malo ſemel mori, quàm tot pharmacis excarnificatus.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Fac igitur ut tibi ipſi ſis medicus.
Si homini diffidis medico, precor ut ſit tibi medici vice deus.
Proinde à Deo pete ſanitatis benificium.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: An non beneficium eſt liberari morbo?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ego autem peto à Deo nihil, niſi quod optimum ſit.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: cùm enim petimus à deo bona,
ad hanc vitam neceſſaria, ſemper addendum eſt, Domine ſi tu vis.
Spiritualia autem & aeterna bona petenda ſunt à Deo ſine ulla conditione.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Et tu vale in craſtinum, ô chariſſime Henrice.

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: HAve you had a a good journey?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: but that there was much robbing every where.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Did you come on foot, or on horſeback?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Part of the way on fooot,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How goe things in the Low-Countries?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: There are great threatnings of warre.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But let this paſſe, we have nothing to doe with fighting.

sp.speaker: Tho
sp.p:
It cannot be worſe
with me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Have you not gained what you purſued?
Have you not the game you hunted?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I hunted, but Delia was not propitious.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hath the Conſul ſent thee nothing?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You muſt therefore feed your ſelfe with hope.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But this will not fill the belly.
Yet I am the more nimble for travell,
becauſe I had no weight in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I confeſſe, and the leſſe in danger,
for there are no greater defenſives against Thieves.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But I had rather have the burden with the danger.
Were not you rob'd by the way?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee how can you plunder a naked man?
Others had more cauſe to feare me.
I could without money in my purſe,
ſing, and be hungry all the way.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But whither are you bound now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: to ſalute my Wife, and Parents,
whom I have not ſeen a great while.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I wiſh you may find all cheerfull there.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So ſay I, and it be Gods will.
Is there no news at our houſe?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you will finde your family increaſed:
for your hen hath laid you a very faire Egge.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You tell me a fine ſtory,
I beſtow this gift upon you,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: This is a very acceptable preſent.
I will ſtudy to recompenſe this favour.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Account, you have ſufficiently requited it,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: niſi quod nihil uſquam tutum eſt à latronibus.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Quo in ſtatu ſunt res Belgicae?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sed haec omittamus, nihil enim nobis cum Marte.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: An proſpero fortunae ſtatu uteris tu?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Res mea in pejori
ſtatu eſſe non poteſt.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sed ſum ad iter expeditior hoc,
quòd nihil eſſet oneris in zona.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: nulla enim ſunt arma certiora adverſus latrones.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nihílne tibi ademptum eſt in via?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Aliis citiùs erat periculum à me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Precor illic ut offendas omnia laeta.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nihil interim extitit novi domi noſtrae?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nihil, niſi quòd reperies auctam familiam:
nam tua gallina peperit tibi pulchrum ovum.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Eſt mihi hoc munus longè gratiſſimum.
Diſpiciam unde poſſim hoc donum penſare.

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: as will more then fraight a Ship.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Ʋnload as ſoon as you can,
leſt you ſink under the burden.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I have no other then what is talked of,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: What? is our Countrey free from the Plague?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: but it ſeem'd otherwiſe to God.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Corne muſt be very dear in that place.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: There is a ſcarſity of all things,

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: there is no sparing Churches nor learning.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Therefore Xenophon ſaid well and wiſely,
Men account peace a very good thing,
But I will detaine you no longer.
We will talke more another time,
when it ſhall be convenient for both.
Now ſome buſineſſe calls me to another place.

sp.speaker: Joa.
sp.p: Nihil habeo praeter ea quae jactantur,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Quid? an patria noſtra immunis à peſte?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: ibi nec ſacris templis nec Muſis parcitur.

sp.speaker: Joa.
sp.p: Pax videtur hominibus eſſe magnum bonum,
Nunc aliò me vocant negotia quaedam.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I Heare you have lately viſited

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I have looked upon it again,
for I had not ſeen my Parents a great while,
the abſence of my Countrey and friends.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You are of a good nature,

the Country wherein
we were bred and borne.
how you found all things there?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Me thought I came into another world
I had ſcarce been abſent ten years.
I did no leſs wonder at all things,
then Epimenides the Prince of ſleepers,
I'le tell you, if you be at leiſure to heare it.
Therefore I pray give me a ſtool and cuſhion.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You will tell a lye with the more eaſe while you ſit.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: of one Epimenides a Cretan borne,
who going alone out of the City
a ſudden ſtorme of raine enforcing;
entring into a Cave he fell aſleep,
and continued ſleeping ſeven and forty years.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But it was well for Epimenides
that he came to himſelfe at laſt.
But you doe like a Poet,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Going therefore to the City, he enquires.
Nor doe I wonder that this happened to Epimenides,
when almoſt the ſame thing hath hapned to me,
who had been abſent but a few yeares.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How doe your Father and Mother?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This is the Comedy of humane life,
Nothing doth laſt long in the ſame condition.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: diu enim non videram parentes meos,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
ejus regionis quae
nos aluit & edidit.
quónam in loco illic offendiſti omnia?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Videbar mihi in alium venire mundum.
Sellam igitur cum pulvino mihi poni jube.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: quadraginta ſeptē perpetuos annos ſomnū continuarit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sed bene cum Epimenide actum eſt,
Sed facis ut poeta dignum eſt.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ut in eodem nihil uſquam duret ſtatu.

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: The firſt Fable. The Kid, and the Wolfe.
div.p: A Kid ſtanding upon the top of an houſe,
It is not thou doſt revile me,

div.head: The ſecond Fable. The Lyon and the Frog.
div.p: A Lyon hearing a Frog creaking aloud,
thinking it to be ſome great Beaſt;
as ſoon as he ſaw what it was,
he trod it under his foot.

div.head: The Morall.
div.p: that we ought not to be troubled
at the report of any thing,

div.head: Fabula ſecunda. Leo & Rana.
div.p: cùm Leo audiviſſet valde ranam clamantem,

div.head: The third Fable. The Hart, and the Lyon.
div.p: A Hart flying from the Hunters,
but meeting there with a Lyon,
ſhe was ſeized upon by him.
I am falne upon the worſt of Beaſts.

div.head: Fabula tertia. Cerva & Leo.
div.p: in Leonem autem ibi cùm incidiſſet,

div.head: The fourth Fable. The Sow and the Bitch.
div.p: A Sow & a Bitch did contend
that ſhe was the moſt fruitfull
of all Creatures upon the earth.
we know you bring forth but blinde Puppies.

div.head: Fabula quarta. Sus & Canis.
div.p: novimus te caecos tuos parere catulos.

div.head: The fifth Fable. The Piper, and the Fiſhes.
div.p: A Piper taking with him his Net and his Pipes,
hoping it would come to paſſe,
that the fiſhes would take to land,
at the ſweetneſſe of his melody.
But when a good while, he could not prevaile,
he put up his Pipes, and betook him to his Nets;
and caſting them into the Sea,
he drew a multitude of fiſhes.
But ſhaking them out of his Net,
ſince you would not dance at all
it is too late now to make me any ſport.
that every thing is to be diſcommended,

div.head: Fabula quinta. Tibicen & Piſces.
div.p: nunc quidem ceſſate mihi idipſum facere.

div.head: The ſixth Fable. An old Man and Death.
div.p: WHen an old man had out ſome Wood,
and when he had laid downe his burden
and asked him the the reaſon
Only that you would help me up with my burden.
that every man loves his life,
although he be unhappy and a Begger.

div.head: The ſeventh Fable. The Aſſe and the Foxe.
div.p: AN Aſſe having put on a Lions skin,
but that I heard you bray,
I ſhould have been terrified too.
which ſeem to be of ability to ſtrangers,

div.head: The eighth Fable. The Dog and the Cook.
div.p: A Dog coming into the Kitchin,
and while the Cook was buſie,
as he spied him running away,
I will be watchfull of thee.
For thou haſt not taken a heart from me,
but thou hast given me a heart.

div.head: Fabula octava. Canis & Coquus.
div.p: Non enim à me cor abſtuliſti,

div.head: The ninth Fable. A woman and a Hen.
div.p: A Certain Widow woman had a Hen,
which every day laid her an egge.
that if ſhe gave her Hen more barly,
ſhe would lay twice a day.
was never after worth an egge.
that they which out of covetouſneſſe

div.head: Fabula nona. Mulier & Gallina.
div.p: quòd ſi plus gallinae hordei projiceret,

div.head: The tenth Fable. The Hen that laid golden Eggs.
div.p: ſuppoſing there was ſtore of Gold within her,
though it neceſſary to kill her:
but when ſhe had killed her,
ſhe found her like other Hens.
ſhe loſt that little which ſhe had.
that we ought to content our ſelves
with what we have, and not to be transported with inſatiable deſires.

div.head: Fabula decima. Gallina aurum pariens.
div.p: rata intra ipſam auri pondus eſſe,

div.head: The eleventh Fable. The Tortoiſe and the Eagle.
div.p: that he would teach him to fly.

that it was farre
his nature:
The other was the more importunate.
He took him therefore up in his talons,
he was broken againſt a rock.
when they will not hearken to men that give them good counſell.

div.head: Fabula undecima. Teſtudo & Aquila
div.p:
procul hoc ab
natura ejus eſſe:

div.head: Μῦθος ια.
div.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: The twelfth Fable. The Blackmore.
div.p: A Certaine Man bought a Blackmore,
Thinking that his colour was ſuch,
by the negligence of him that had him before.
he applied all manner of purgations to him,
with all waſhing to make him white:
but he could not change his colour,
and had his labour for his paine.
as they were in the beginning.

div.head: Fabula duodecima. Aethiops.
div.p: negligentia ejus qui priùs eum habuerat.

div.head: The thirteenth Fable. The Boar and the Fox.
div.p: A Boar ſtanding neer to a tree,
But a Fox asking the cauſe,
why upon no neceſſity that urged him,
I doe not this without reaſon:
for if any danger ſurpriſe me,
I ſhall not then be at leiſure
but rather to make uſe of them.
that it behoveth one to be alwayes prepared

div.head: Fabula decima tertia. Aper & Vulpes.
div.p: A Per cùm cuidem adſtabat arbori,
nam ſi periculum me aliquod ininvaſerit,

div.head: The fourteenth Fable. The Crow.
div.p: Mother pray to God for me,
What God will take compaſsion of thee?
For whoſe fleſh haſt thou not preyed upon?
they that have many enemies in this life,

div.head: Fabula decima quarta. Corvus.
div.p: Cujus enim caro à te non ſurrepta eſt?
qui multos habent in vita inimicos,

div.head: The fifteenth Fable. The Fox and the Lion.
div.p: THe Fox having never ſeen a Lion,
when he met him by chance,
was ſo terrified at the firſt,
that he was ready to give up the ghoſt.
the ſecond time he ſaw him,
but not ſo much as before.
But when he ſaw him the third time,
that he approached and talked to him.
things otherwiſe formidable, eaſily to be attempted.

div.head: The ſixteenth Fable. The Graſhopper and the Ant.
div.p: when Corne was moiſt with heat,
the Ants did aire it abroad.
Why did you not gather food in the Summer?
I spent my time in ſinging.
Then they laughing at him returned,
If you have ſung away the Summer,
you may now dance in the Winter.
that it becomes not a man
when he is thrown upon neceſſities.

div.head: The ſeventeenth Fable. Jupiter.
div.p: invited all the Beaſts to a banquet.
wondring at the cauſe of his ſlowneſſe,
why ſhe came not to the ſupper.
that ſhe ſhould alwayes carry her houſe like a Porter.
then with the higheſt entertainment abroad.

div.head: Fabula decima ſeptima. Jupiter.
div.p: cur ipſa ad coenam non adfuiſſet.

div.head: The eighteenth Fable. The Horſe and the Aſſe.
div.p: A Certaine man had an Horſe and an Aſſe.
As they were travelling upon the way,
the Aſſe ſaid to the Horſe,
Take a part of my burthen,
But he would not be perſwaded.
The Aſſe ſinking under his burthen dyed.
But the Maſter laying the whole load upon the Horſe,
and the very skin of the Aſſe,
What is hapned to me a wretch?
For I that was not willing
that when the great ones communicate with the ſmall,

div.head: Fabula decima octava. Equus & Aſinus.
div.p: Aſinus cadens ex labore vitam finivit.
quòd ubi cum parvis magni communicant,

div.head: The ninteenth Fable. Thieves.
div.p: found nothing but a dunghill Cock,
and ſeizing upon him they went their way.
But when he came to be kill'd,
he petitioned them to be diſmiſt,
pretending that he was neceſſary to men,
as one that in the night called them up to worke.
for this very reaſon we kill thee,
that thoſe things are moſt contrary to evill men,
which are benefits to the good.

div.head: Fabula decima nona. Fures.
div.p: Cùm autem eſſet ab ipſis mactandus,
ut qui eos noctu ad opera excitaret.

div.head: The twentieth Fable. The nightingale & the Hawk.
div.p: A Nightingale perching upon the tree,
did ſing according to her cuſtome.
A Hawk ſeeing her and being hungry,
But when ſhe was to be ſlaine,
that ſhe might not be devoured,
as not ſufficient to ſatisfie his hunger,
but that it was fit for him in his neceſſity,
to flye upon other greater birds.
if I let the food goe now in my hands,
to follow a new game not viſible.
that ſome men are ſo inconſiderate,
that they loſe what they have in their power,
with hope of greater things only in the aire.

div.head: Fabula viceſima. Philomela & Accipiter.
div.p: non ſatis eſſe ad accipitris ventrem implendum,
ſi dimittens eſcam in manibus paratam,

div.head: The one & twentieth Fable. Youngmen and a Cook.
div.p: Two young men ſtood neer a Cook,
and while the Cook was buſie at his worke,
one of them ſtealing a piece of fleſh,
conveyed it into the others boſome.
But the Cook, turning himſelfe about,
ſwore that he had it not;
But when the Cook perceived their craft,
Although I cannot finde you out,
yet you are not undiſcovered to God,
that though our perjuries are not known to men,
we cannot put on a vizor before God.

div.head: Fabula viceſima prima. Adoleſcentuli & Coquus.
div.p: & Coquo in aliquo domeſtico opere occupato,
At coquus ubi ſenſit nequitiam illorum,

div.head: The two and twentieth Fable. A Husbandman & his two Sons.
div.p: and deſiring that his Sons ſhould follow their Husbandry;
I am now going out of this world.
what I have hid in the Vineyard,
that there was ſome treaſure hid there,
dig'd all the Earth of the Vineyard,
But the Vineyard thus very well digged,
and the beſt recompence of our expectations.

div.head: Fabula viceſima ſecunda. Agricola & filii ejus.
div.p: & volens filios ſuos periculum facere agriculturâ;
quae in vinea à me occultata ſunt

div.head: The three and twentieth Fable. The Frogs.
div.p: TWo Frogs were bred in a Marſh.
But the Marſh being dryed up
and found out a deep well.
Let us deſcend into this pit.
But if this water ſhall become dry,
how ſhall we get up againe?

div.head: The four and tweneth Fable. Foxes.
div.p: A Fox taken in a ſnare,
and getting off with the loſſe of his taile,
thought he could not live without diſhonour.
to adviſe other Foxes to it,
that he might hide his particular ſhame,
And truly having called them all together,
he counſailed them to cut off their tailes,
becauſe this member was not onely uncomely,
but that the burden upon it was unneceſſary.
But if this were not an advantage to your ſelf,
you doe ill to engage us to it.
not out of good will to their friends,

div.head: Fabula viceſima quarta. Vulpes.
div.p: non vivendam prae ignominia ducebat vitam.
quòd non ſolùm indecorum eſſet hoc membrum,
Verùm ſi tibi hoc non conduceret,

div.head: The five and twentieth Fable. Mercury, and the Statuary.
div.p: what reputation he had among men,
went to the houſe of an Image-maker,
taking upon him the ſhape of a Man.
And spying the ſtatue of Iupiter,
for what price it might be bought.
But anſwer being made for a drachm,
He laughing, asked the price of Juno's.
But he anſwered, it was dearer.
And ſeeing his own ſtatue there,
becauſe he was the meſſenger of the Gods,
that a great eſtimation ſhould be had of him
I will give you this into the bargain.
againſt a man that is covetous of his owne vaine glory,
who hath no honour among other men.

div.head: Fabula viceſima quinta. Mercurius & Statuarius.
div.p: in quanto honore apud homines eſſet,
qui in nullo eſt honore apud alios.

div.head: The ſixe and twentieth Fable. The Wolfe and the Crane.
div.p: A Bone ſtuck within a Wolfs throat,
to give a reward to the Crane,
he would take a bone out of his throat.
But when he had drawn it forth,
that your head hath eſcaped ſafe and ſound,
having been once in the mouth and teeth of a Wolfe.
that it is vaine to aske a reward
from men above us in power,
if they forbeare to hurt us.

div.head: Fabula viceſima ſexta. Lupus & Grus.
div.p: quòd extuliſti caput ſalvum & nihil paſſum,

div.head: The ſeven & twentieth Fable. A Fiſherman.
div.p: A Fiſherman did fiſh in a certaine river,
and when he had ſet his nets.
that the Fiſhes in their flight might unawares be engaged in his net.
But one that did inhabit there about,
chid him, as one that troubled the River,
and would not let them drinke the water pure.
If the River ſhould not be thus troubled,
when they bring their Countrey into ſedition.

div.head: Fabula viceſima ſeptima. Piſcator.
div.p: ut piſces fugientes incautè in retia inciderent.
Quidam autem eorum qui circa locum habitabat,

div.head: The twenty eighth Fable. The Wolfe and the old Woman.
div.p: But coming to a certaine place,
and an old Woman ſaying to him,
or i'le give you up to the Wolfe
The Wolfe thinking the old Woman ſpoke in earneſt,
ſtaid there expecting a long houre.
he heares the old Woman againe,
As ſoon as the Wolf heard this,
This Fable is againſt thoſe men,

div.head: The twenty ninth Fable. Dogs.
div.p: the one he bred up to hunting,
the other to keep the houſe.
And if at any time it hapned
the hound to take any game,
the Dog that tarried at home, had his ſhare of the prey.
But the hound taking it ill,
becauſe he every day took the pains,
Accuſe not me, but our Maſter,
who taught not me to labour,
but to eate other folkes meat.
that young men that are ignorant,
when their Parents gave them no better education.

div.head: Fabula viceſima nona. Canes.
div.p: etiam qui domi remanebat particeps erat praedae.
quòd etiam juvenes qui nihil ſciunt,

div.head: The thirtieth Fable. The man which broke an Image.
div.p: A Certaine man having a wooden god,
that he would doe ſomthing for him.
When he had done this often,
and lived still in great want,
he took him by the legs,
and threw him againſt the pavement.
But his head knocking the ground,
a great deal of gold came forth:
which when the man had gathered up,
for thou didſt me no good
but thou doſt beſtow many good things
That you ſhall profit your ſelf nothing
But if you laſh him ſoundly,
you may get the more benefit by him.

div.head: Fabula triceſima. Homo qui confregit statuam.
The one and twentieth Fable. A Woman and her Maids.
div.p: A Widow woman that took pains for her living,
uſed to call them up in the night
But they wearied out with continuall labour,
thought fit to kill the Cock in the houſe,
as one that waked their Miſtreſſe in the night.
But it fell out with them when they had done this,
that they fell into greater inconveniences;
for the Miſtreſſe n •• knowing the Cocks houre,
called them up more early in the night.
their own counſells are the cauſe of their ruine.

div.head: Fabula triceſima prima. Mulier & Ancillae.
div.p: exiſtimarunt oportere gallum interficere qui domi eſſet,
Contigit autem ipſis hoc quum effeciſſent,

div.head: The two and thirtieth Fable. The Cat and the Cock.
div.p: A Cat when ſhe had caught a Cock,
was willing to devour him upon ſome juſt pretence,
ſaying, that he was troubleſome to men,
not ſuffering them to enjoy their ſleep.
that they might be called to their uſuall labour;
that he was impious againſt nature,
by committing with his owne Mother and Siſters.
for the benefit of his Maſters,
ſince by this they gained many eggs;
Although you abound with pregnant reaſons,
yet I will not ſtay long faſting;
that a nature reſolved to doe miſchief,
if he cannot doe it by any colourable pretext,

div.head: Fabula triceſima ſecunda. Felis & Gallus.
div.p: quum multa hinc ova ipſis pariantur;
ſi veriſimili praetextu id facere non poſſit,

div.head: The three and thirtieth fable. An impious man.
div.p: Therefore taking a Sparrow in his hand,
and hiding it under his coat.
He ſtood next to the Tripod,
whether is that living or dead,
which I hold in my hand?
that if he ſaid it were dead,
he would ſhew the sparrow alive:
but if he ſaid he were living,
But the God knowing his malitious deſigne,
It it not in thy power,
to do what thou haſt a liſt to.
Thou doſt hold a thing that is dead,
and thinking to confute the God.
he ſhewed the Sparrow dead indeed.
that no policy can deceive the Deity,
and that there is no jugling with God.

div.head: Fabula triceſima tertia. Maleficus.
div.p: ad eum qui eſt Delphis venerat Apollinem,

Ita
que cum ſumpſiſſet paſſerculum in manu,
Sed deus malitioſam ejus cognoſcens mentem,
quòd numen divinum nullis rationibus fallitur,

div.head: The four and thirtieth Fable. The Boy and his Mother.
div.p: A Boy having ſtole pins and
But becauſe ſhe chid him not,
but rather content to be the receiver;
in time growing to be a young man,
he began to ſteale greater matters.
But at laſt taken in the very theft,
he was led ſtraight to execution.
that he might ſpeak a few words to his Mother
But as ſoon as ſhe had applyed her ſelfe to her Sons mouth,
he bit off one of her eares.
But his Mother, and others condemning him,
that he had not onely plaid the theif,
But had been impipious to his Mother:
ſhe was the Author of his ruine:
for if ſhe had puniſhed me,
I had not come to this point.
which, are not puniſhed in the beginning.

div.head: Fabula triceſima quarta. Puer & Mater.
div.p: In ipſo autem furto aliquando deprehenſus,
Haec verò cùm continuò ori ſe filii admoviſſet,
ſed jam etiam in matrem impius eſſet:

div.head: The five and thirtieth Fable. An old woman and a Phyſician.
div.p: AN old woman having ſore eyes,
that if he could cure her,
that ſhe would give him what ſhe promiſed:
but if not, ſhe would give him nothing.
Well, the Phyſician went upon his cure.
But every day he came to the old woman
when ſhe could not ſee that houre
not without ſtealeing ſomething or other out of her houſe.
The old woman ſaw her houſhold ſtuffe diminiſh
nothing was left her at all, when ſhe was cured.
But when the Phyſitian demanded of her
as from one perfectly reſtored to ſight,
Now more aſſuredly I ſee nothing.
For when my eyes were weake,
I could perceive many things in my houſe,
but now you affirme I can ſee perfectly,
I can diſcerne nothing at all.
that evill men in what they doe,

div.head: Fabula triceſima quinta. Anus & Medicus.
div.p: Cùm illa nequaquam videre poſpoſſet eâ horâ
At medicus cum efflagitaret ab ea
nunc autem cùm tu me videre inquis,
quòd pravi homines in iis quae agant,

div.head: The ſixe and thirtieth Fable. A Man and a Dog.
div.p: and his Dog did invite another, ſaying,
Oh my friend, come you and ſup with me!
What joy on the ſodaine hath raviſhed me!
and eate my belly full at ſupper,
that I ſhall not poſſibly be a hungry to morrow.
While the Dog was grumbling this to himſelfe,
as the Cook spied him whirling his taile,
taking him up by the heels,
he threw him out of the window.
But after his fall, he went away howling.
Another Dog that met him in the way,
that I know not which way I came forth.
that we ought not to truſt thoſe,

div.head: Fabula triceſima ſexta. Homo & Canis.
div.p: & Canis ipſius alium canem vocabat, dicens,
O amice, huc veni coenatum mecum!
Quantū mihi gaudium nunc mihi derepente effulſit!
ita ut cras nullâ ratione eſuriam.
coquus ut vidit eum caudam vertentem
Ille verò delapſus abiit valde clamans.
Aliquis autem canum qui in via ei occurrebant,
neque viam ipſam unde egreſſus ſum novi.

div.head: Fable the ſeven and thirtieth. A Carpenter and Mercury.
div.p: A Man cutting wood over a River,
Not knowing what to doe therefore,
and asked whether that were it
But he ſaying that this was not it,
He going down again brought up a ſilver one:
That this was not it neither;
But he affirming that this was truly his owne,
And letting his hatchet fall into the River,
And when Mercury appeared alſo to him,
and learned the cauſe of his weeping;
going downe in the ſame manner,
he brought up a golden hatchet,
whether that were the ſame which he had loſt.
the God displeaſed at ſo great impudence,
but alſo not returned him his own.
that as much as the Divine power favoureth the juſt,
ſo much he is an enemy to the wicked.

div.head: Fabula triceſima ſeptima. Lignator & Mercurius.
div.p: QUidam ligna ſcindens lignator apud fluvium,
Illo verò, non hanc eſſe dicente,
Illo autem hanc verè eſſe, dicente,
Et propriam ſecurim cùm diniſiſſet in fluvium,

div.head: The eight and thirtieth Fable. The Lyon and the Foxe.
div.p: reſolved to do ſomething by ſubtilty.
Withdrawing himſelfe therefore into his Cave,
and ſeizing upon thoſe beaſts that came
After many beaſts were thus eaten,
he asked him how he did.
why he did not come in?
Becauſe I ſee the footſteps of many
that have entred into your Cave,
but the print of very few feet that have come back againe.

div.head: The nine and thirtieth Fable. A Woman and her drunken Huſband.
div.p: A Certain Woman had a drunkard to her Husband:
but ſhe willing to recover him from this infirmity,
For when ſhe obſerved him overcharged with drink,
and like a dead man without any ſenſe,
taking him up on her ſhoulders,
ſhe laid him downe in a vault,
But when ſhe thought he was come to himſelfe,
ſhe went and knocked at the doore of the Vault.
Who is that which knocks at the door?
I am come to bring ſome meat to the dead.
And he ſaid, O my deare friend!
if you have remembred food, and not liquor.
But ſhe ſtriking her breaſt, ſaid,
for I have profited nothing by my policy:
for thou my Husband, art worſe then thou wert,
thy diſeaſe is grown into a habit,
and thou wilt be drunk when thou art dead.
that we ought not to dwell upon evill acts:
for a bad custome doth beget a habit,

div.head: Fabula triceſima nona. Mulier, & vir ebrius.
div.p: Qum enim obſervaſſet eum aggravatum ab ebrietate,
Quum verò ipſum jam ſobrium eſſe conjectaret,
in habitum tibi deductus eſt morbus,
mala enim conſuetudo in habitum deducetur.

div.head: The fortieth Fable. The Lyon and the Wolfe.
div.p: All the Beaſts came to viſit their King,
The wolfe therefore taking this occaſion,
accuſed the Fox to the Lyon,
as one that did not honour their generall Lord,
and therefore came not to viſit him.
The Foxe came in at that time,
and heard the laſt words of the Wolfe.
The Lyon therefore began to rage againſt him;
but the Foxe deſiring leave to acquit himſelfe,
And who of thoſe that are here,
hath done ſo much ſervice as my ſelf?
who have travailed through all parts,
and enquired of the Phyſicians a remedy for you,
But the Lyon commanding him preſently to ſpeak it;
If you put on the warme skin
It does not become you ſo to inflame our Lord to indignation,
but rather to diſpoſe him to gentleneſs.
that he that doth plot conſtantly to hang other men,
doth ſometime prepare a halter for himſelfe.

div.head: Fabula quadrageſima. Leo & Lupus.
div.p: ut qui nihili faciebat ſuum omnium dominum,
ſed vulpes defenſionis tempus cùm petiiſſet,
& medicamentum pro te à medicis quaeſivi,
Quum autem Leo ſtatim ut medicamentum diceret imperaſſet;
Non ſic oportet dominum movere ad malevolentiam,

div.head: Menippus and Mercury. Menippus & Mercurius. Μένιππος καί Ἑρμῆς.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: O Mercury, where be all theſe gay men,
conduct me a ſtranger to them.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: and yet look on that place,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And yet theſe are the bones,
which all your Poets have admired,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: for I did not know her.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Were ſo many Ships fraught for this,
ſo many Greeks and Barbarians ſlain,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But you never ſaw this woman alive Menippus.
You would not have blamed your ſelf
to have ſuffered miſery a long time,
Thus it is with withered flowers,
if a man look upon them when they have loſt their beauty,
they will ſeem very unpleaſant to thee.
But when they are in their flouriſh,
and have their glory upon them,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: But this I admire at Mercury,
that the Greeks underſtood not themſelves, to ſuffer [ſo much]
for a thing of ſo ſmall a continuaance,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am not at leiſure Menippus,
to dispute the Philoſophy with you.
Wherefore if you will chuſe a place,
I wil call ſome more of the dead preſently.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: O Mercuri, ubinam illi formoſi ſunt,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Itane mille naves propter hanc repletae ſunt,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Sed non vidiſti Menippe mulierem viventem.
ſi quis aſpiciat ubi abjecerunt colorem,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: ſi non Graeci intellexerunt ſe laborare

div.head: Menippus and Cerberus. Menippus & Cerberus. Μέννιππος καί Κέρβερος.
div.p: for I am a kinſman of yours,
a Dog as well as your ſelfe,
when he came down to you?
that you being a God, doe not onely barke,
but can speak like a man

sp.speaker: Cerb.
sp.p: At a diſtance he ſeemed Menippus,
to approach us wholly with a compoſed countenance,
as one that had little feare of death:
and this he ſeemed willing ſhould appeare,
to them that ſtood without the gate.
But when he perceived the vaſt Chaſma or gaping within,
and that I had bitten him with my poiſon,
I drag'd him by the heels,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: and did not truly deſpiſe the matter.

sp.speaker: Cerb.
sp.p: No, but when he ſaw there was a neceſſity,
he took upon him a confidence,
that the ſpectators might admire him.
And clearly I can ſay thus of them all,
they are bold and valiant in their tongues,
but within their conviction is manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: But in what manner did I appeare

sp.speaker: Cerb.
sp.p: proclaiming ſorrow to all the world beſide.

sp.speaker: Cerb.
sp.p: Non, ſed ubi rem neceſſariam videbat,
Et planè de omnibus illis dicere poſſum,

div.head: Pluto Πλούτων. Proteſilaus Πρωτεσίλαος. Proſerpina Περσεφόνη

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: What doſt thou beg from us?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: and the firſt man that was ſlain at Troy.
My ſuit is to be diſmiſſed for a very ſmall time

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: all dead men are at this love,
but none of them can obtaine.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: it is not life that I affect,
afterwards unhappily I was ſlaine by Hector,
Therefore the love of my deare wife,
O Sir, doth much afflict me,
and I deſire to returne again,

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: but this was a far more weighty buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: for ſhe will come hither in time,
and you ſhall not need to goe to her.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: But I have not patience to tarry,
you have been your ſelfe a lover,

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: But what good will it doe you
to live againe for a day,

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: I am confident I can perſwade her
in a little time you ſhall receive two.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Let me put you in remembrance Oh Pluto!
You gave back Eurydice to Orpheus,
and you ſent my Couſin Alceſtes,

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: being ſuch a naked & deformed skull,
to appeare before your beautifull Bride?
and how will ſhe look upon you,
not being able to know you again?
I know ſhe will be frighted,
and then you will make a pilgrimage back to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.p: as ſoon as Proteſilaus comes into the light,
upon the ſtroke of his wand,
to make the young man as beautifull,
as he was when he came forth of his bride chamber.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: that you have but one day.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.p: Tu verò quâ re indiges a nobis?

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: deinde infelix ſum occiſus ab Hectore,

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: res autem illa longè gravior erat.

sp.speaker: Prot.
sp.p: Revocabo in memoriam tibi O Pluto!

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: and deſire to exalt your ſelfe above us all?

sp.speaker: Mauſ.
sp.p: For the vastneſſe of my Empire, O Sinopian,
And tamed many of the Lydians.
reducing many parts of Jonia under my dominions.
I was alſo beautifull and tall,
But that which is moſt famous of all,
In Halicarnaſſus I have a moſt ſumptuous Sepulchre,
above any other of the dead,
with Men and Horſes exactly carved,
ſuch as no man can find a temple to compare with it.
that I boaſt juſtly for this magnificence?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: and the dignity of your Tombe?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p:
neither is that
ſtrength any longer your owne,
for if we chooſe any man to be judge
I cannot ſee for what reaſon
your ſconce ſhould be preferred to mine.
They are both bald and naked,
and our flat noſes ſnuffle alike upwards.
But your Sepulchre and pretious ſtones
that indeed there is ſuch a gallant pile amongst them.
I ſee not what you enjoy from it,
becauſe you carry a greater weight then we,
whiles you lye under the preſſure of ſuch heavy ſtones.

sp.speaker: Mauſ.
sp.p: Are all theſe things things then unprofitable to me?
and are Mauſolus and Diogenes equalls?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Not equalls excellent Sir, by no meanes.
with the remembrance of thoſe things upon earth,
But Diogenes ſhall laugh at him,
and ſay the Monument at Halicarnaſſus,
was built at the charges of his wife Artemiſia, and his Siſter.
whether his body have a buriall, or no,
nor is he at all troubled at it.
But he hath left a fame behind him,
of one that lived a life worthy of a man,
and built upon a more ſolid foundation.

sp.speaker: Mauſ.
sp.p: In Halicarnaſſo ſepulchrum habeo maximum impoſitum,
quale neque templum inveniat aliquis facilé.
juſtè propter haec magnifica ſuper bire?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: non poſsū dicere, cujus rei causâ
quòd ſcilicet magna aliqua ſtructura eſt apud ipſos.
non video quam utilitatem capias ex eo,
quòd onus geſtas quàm nos majus,

sp.speaker: Mauſ.
sp.p: Inutilia igitur mihi ſunt illa omnia?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: & ſepulchrum quidem in Halicarnaſſo dicet ſuum,
ut qut peregerit vitam viro dignam,

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: ARe you come O Polyſtratus at laſt,
I think almoſt one hundred yeers old?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But how have you liv'd theſe thirty yeers after me?
when you were about threeſcore and ten.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: although this may appeare ſtrange to you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: if being both old and infirme,
you could indulge your ſelfe with things of this life.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
for I had many fine
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
lads,
and my wines with a flavour,
and my tables above the Sicilian luxury.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But I had plenty of all choice things
and afterwards I was preſented with gifts of every kind,
the faireſt of all the world.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Did you reign after me Polyſtratus?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: but I had an infinite many lovers.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: with two brace of teeth in your head?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, the greateſt men of the City

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And ſhe after, upon your Petition, granted you

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not ſo, but in the condition I was,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But this love is often manifeſt
to men that have no children,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now I underſtand your beauty admirable Sir,
it was from your golden Venus.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: However, I received no ſmall benefit from theſe ſweethearts,
But I carried my ſelf high,
and ſometime excluded ſome of them.
Then were they at a contention

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How did you dispoſe of your wealth?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Truly I did in publique declare,
that I would make every one of them my heire.
And every one ſwallowed the beliefe,
and became more obſequious to me.
But having the other true inſtruments of my will, I left them,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Whom did thoſe laſt tables declare your heire?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And yet he was more worthy then they,
whom now the very grandees Court.
and is now regiſtred among the Patritians,
and reported more wiſe then Ulyſſes himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
let him be Generall
of all the Graecian Armies,
but let not them be his heires alone.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: annos puto non multo pauciores centum vivens?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Quomodo autem vixiſti hos triginta annos poſt me?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: laetari iis quae ſunt in vita poteras.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
inſuper & pueri elegantes
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
erant multi,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: poſt autem, omnis generis mihi dona adducebantur,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Atqui manifeſtus hic amor eſt crebrò,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nunc teneo tuam pulchritudinem, ô admirande,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Caeterùm non exigua ab amatoribus percepi commoda,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sed alias veras teſtamenti tabulas illas habens, reliqui,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Quem igitur ultimae illae haeredem habuerunt?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Quot natum annos circiter, ô Polyſtrate?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: illi autem non haeredes ſint ſolùm.

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,

sp.speaker: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
sp.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: And are you dead Alexander, like one of us?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You ſee Diogenes: nor is it any wonder,
if being a man I am mortall.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: ſaying that you were his Son;
it ſeems you were the Son of Philip.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But the like was ſaid of Olympias,
That a Dragon mixt with her,
and was ſeen in her bed,
and that you were ſo begot.
ſuppoſing that he was your Father.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I heard theſe things as well as you,

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But yet their lies O Alexander
out of the beliefe that you were a God.
But tell me prethee, to whom did you leave

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: for I had not time enough
to determine any thing about it,
I gave a ring to Perdiccas.
But why doſt thou laugh Diogenes?

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: flattering you, when you took upon you the Kingdome,
as to the Son of the Dragon?
where did the Macedonians bury thee?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As yet I lye dead in Babylon,
But Ptolemy of my life guard promiſeth,
when he ſhall be at leiſure
from the tumults now on foot,
that he will tranſlate me to Egypt,
and there I ſhall be buried,

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Shall I not laugh O Alexander,
ſeeing thee dote in theſe infernall ſhades,
and hoping to be made Anubis or Oſiris?
But O thou moſt divine thing,
doe not cheriſh ſuch a hope:
that any of thoſe ſhould returne,
which have once paſſed the lake,
But this I would faine learn from thee,
what happineſſe you forſaking upon earth,
your head bound with white Ribbands,
Do not thoſe things ſad your heart,
when they come back to your memory?
your wiſe Ariſtotle taught you not
to think theſe things of Fortune permanent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: he was the moſt impious flatterer of men.
Give me leave to know onely what Ariſtotle did,
what large boones he asked me,
ſaying, that this was a part of beatitude:
for this he thought was a bleſſing,
that he might not bluſh ô Diogenes,
But this fruit I had from his wiſdom,
to lament the loſſe of thoſe excellent things
which you repeated but even now.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: But doe you know what to doe?
I will teach you a cure for your ſorrow.
taking it in with an open mouth,
to mourn for theſe bleſsings of Ariſtotle.
But I ſee Clitus and Calliſthenes,
and many other ruſhing in upon thee,
for thoſe things thou haſt done to them.
and drink often, as I told thee.

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Et tu mortuus es ô Alexander,

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: tu verò Philippi eras nempe filius.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Et ego audiebam haec ſicut tu,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: non enim erat mihi ſat ſpatii

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: neque te haec ſapiens Ariſtoteles docuit,
putare haec ſtabilia eſſe, quae ſunt fortunae.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sine me tantùm Ariſtoteiis facta cognoſcere,
dicens, quod hoc eſſet pars beatitudinis:
Caeterū hunc fructum percepi ex ejus ſapentia,

sp.speaker: Diog.
sp.p: Itaque alterâ tu hac viâ vade,

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.p: Truly I a Paraſite to Dinias,
was choaked with eating too much,
for you were preſent at my death.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: but mine was an unexpected accident.
You were acquainted with old Pteodorus.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: The rich man that had no children,
with whom I obſerved, you did very much converſe?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: That very man I did alwayes court,
that he would dye for my advantage.
But when it hapned not, after a long expectation,
I found a compendious way to the inheritance:
as ſoon as Pteodorus ſhould call for drink,
when he poured wine into his cup,
and if he would doe this,
I ſwore to make him a Free-man.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: for you tell me a ſtrange ſtory.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: the young man had two cups ready,
by what miſtake I know not,
but to Pteodorus that without poiſon.
but I preſently fell down dead,
Why doe you laugh at this Zenophantes?
Certainly you ought not to jeer your friend.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: You have ſuffered quaintly oh Callidemides.
But what ſaid the old man to this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: At firſt he was ſomewhat troubled
but afterwards underſtanding (as I ſuppoſe) the matter,
and the Cup-bearer at what he had done.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: Surely you need not have put your ſelfe upon ſuch a ſtraight:
he would have come to you by the common roade more ſafely,
though he had not come ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.p: plus juſto cùm manducaſſem, ſuffocatus ſum,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Sed cùm ea res in longum proferretur,
compendioſam aliquam viam ad haereditatem inveni:

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: valde enim aliquid inexpectatum dicturus videris.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: duos jam adoleſcens calices paratos habens,
Certè non oportebat viro amico illudere.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: Lepida quidem ô Callidemides, paſſus es.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.p: Enimvero neque te ad illud compendium oportebat divertere:
veniſſet tibi per viam regiam ſecuriùs,

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.p: IF you like a mad fellow have kill'd your ſelf Ajax,
and teare us all to pieces,
why doe you raile upon Ʋlyſſes?
And would not a little before look upon him,
when he came hither to conſult the Oracle,
nor would vouchſafe to ſpeak to him,
but in a proud poſture paſſed by him.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: It was but juſt, O Agamemnon,
for he was the cauſe of my madneſſe,
the onely man that did contend with me for the armor.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Would you have a victory without an enemy,

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: for that armour was my owne,
and you that were much before him,
endangered to be cut in pieces by the Trojans,
and pretend his more juſt title to the armes.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Lay the blame then, oh noble Sir, upon Thetis,
who, when ſhe ſhould have given the ſucceſſion of the armour to thee,
but bringing them, ſhe laid them down in the middle.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: It is to be excuſed Ajax,
for which every one of us
the rather, when he overcame you (afterwards)
and that by the judgment of the Trojans.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: I know who ſhe was that condemned me;
but it is ſin to speak ill of the Deities.
I can doe no other then hate Ʋlyſſes,
though Minerva her ſelfe ſhould countermand me.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.p: SI tu inſaniens ô Ajax teipſum occidiſti,

& paulò ante ne
que aſpicere eum voluiſti,
ſed ſuperbè grandi incedens greſſu praeteriiſti.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: ille enim mihi furoris extitit auctor,
ſolus mecum judicio contendens pro armis.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.p: quae, cùm deberet ſucceſſionem armorum tibi tradere,
ſed afferens in medium depoſuit illa.

sp.speaker: Ajax.
sp.p: ſed nefas eſt dicere aliquid de diis.
non ſi ipſa Minerva mihi hoc imperet.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: that when you were a God,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: You have heard a truth ô Menippus,
and I am dead as thou ſeeſt,
when I might have been immortall.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What deſire of death poſſeſt you,
a thing generally diſpleaſing to all?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: I will tell thee, ſeeing thou art a wiſe man.
I was no longer delighted with immortality.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Was it not pleaſant to live and behold the light?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: which hath variety and not a ſimple thing.
But when I was alwayes living,
and enjoying the ſame ſun, light, and food,
and what other things are made,
in the conſtancy of a thing,
but altogether in the change, or variety.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: but how do you like theſe things below,
ſince you choſe to come higher?

sp.speaker: Chir.
sp.p: to be in your light, or in the dark.
Beſide we are ſenſible of no hunger nor thirſt,
but we are not wanting all thoſe things.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Take heed Chiron you contradict not your ſelfe,
and that your tongue falter not in the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Becauſe if the likeneſſe of things, which are in our life,
and the ſame things bred a ſatiety,
ſince here all things are alike,
the ſame diſlike will be upon you,
and there will be a neceſſity to ſeek out ſome change,
and from hence to eſcape into another life,

sp.speaker: Chir.
sp.p: What ſhall one doe then Menippus?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: he that is a wiſe man will acquieſce,
content himſelf with his preſent condition,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Non erat mihi amplius jucundū immortalitate frui.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Non ſuave erat viventem, lucem tueri?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: verùm quo animo fers haec quae apud inferos,

sp.speaker: Chir.
sp.p: in luce eſſe an in tenebris.
Caterùm neque eſurire oportet, neque ſitire,
ſed non egentes horum omnium ſumus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Vide ô Chiron ne incurras in teipſum,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Quoniam ſi ſimilitudo eorum ſemper quae in vita erant,
& cùm hic itidem ſimilia ſint omnia,

sp.speaker: Chir.
sp.p: Quid igitur faciat quis ô Menippe?

div.head: Charon. Mortui. Χάρων. Νεκροὶ. Mercurius. Menippus. Ἑρμῆς. Μένιππος. Charmoleus. Lampichus. Χαρμόλεως. Λάμπιχος. Damaſias. Crato. Δαμασίας. Κράτων. Philoſophus. Φιλόσοφος. Rhetor. Ῥήτωρ.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: HEar in what condition your affaires ſtand,
we have but a ſmall boat,
and if it be inclined on any ſide,
every one bringing many things with him;
and if you come aboard on this faſhion,

I feare you will afterward
repent it,
especially as many as cannot ſwim.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What ſhall we doe then to have a ſafe paſſage?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: you must all come abord naked,
leaving all your ſuperfluous things aſhore,
the boat will hardly receive you then.
And therefore it ſhall be your care Mercury,
to take none of them at preſent,
and hath not caſt away his furniture,
but compel them all to ſtrip.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: and I took a good care to bring no cloak.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But that handſome man, what is he?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: whoſe kiſſe was bought for 2000 talents.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: and your lips together with thoſe kiſſes,
and that roſineſſe upon your cheeks,
But he with the purple robe

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I am Lampichus Prince of the Geloans.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: having ſo many things upon you, Lampichus?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Does it become a Tyrant, Mercury,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: but a dead man without doubt,

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Behold, my treaſure is thrown away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And your pride too, O Lampichus,
they will overcharge the boat if they come in.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: But let me reſerve my Crowne and my Robe.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By no means, you muſt quit them too.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: You ſee I have parted with all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But you thick and brawny Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: having ſeen you often in the wraſtling places.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Not naked oh my famous Sir,
you muſt down with that too,
for you will ſink the boat,
if you put but in one foot,
but you muſt part with thoſe Girlands,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now behold I am perfectly naked as you ſee,
and equall to the reſt of the dead.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So it is better to be light,
neither bring any of your Epitaphs,
nor the honour of your predeceſſors,
the City hath declared you their aſſertor,
and built you any glorious monument,
for theſe memorialls will overlade us.

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p: Though I be not very willing,
yet I will throw them away:

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: why doe you carry this trophy?

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p: Becauſe I am a Conquerour Mercury,
and the City hath honoured me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In the ſhades there is peace,
as I gueſſe by his habit,
he that has the long beard?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Rather an impoſtor full of his cheats,
you will obſerve hid many ridiculous things.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: what a luggage of pride he carries?
By Jove he hath both gold and pleaſure,
for they ſtand diſcovered to me,
though you obſcure them never ſo much.
and to think your ſelf better than others,
for if you bring all theſe into a boat,
what veſſell with five oars in a ſeat will receive you?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: But let him quit his beard Mercury,

it being heavy and
briſtled, as you ſee,
the heires weigh three pound at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You ſay well, come, off with theſe.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Menippus with a Ship-axe ſhall diſpatch it,
and make uſe of the Ship ladder for a block?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No Mercury: give me but a ſaw,
there will be more ſport in it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Look, thou ſheweſt more a man,
having parted with the ſtinke of it.
Shall I pare a little from his eyebrows?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
••• is, for they advance
upon his brow.
I know not why exalting himſelf.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: which hath been very advantageous to him in his life.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And you Menippe caſt off that liberty,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: and your other overcharge of words.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: let us hale up the ladder,
and you moſt of all you Philoſopher;
that loſt your beard ſo lately?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: they are other things afflict him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Becauſe he ſhall not have ſuch coſtly ſuppers,
nor going out in the night,
muffling his head in his Cloak,
he ſhall walke the round about the wanton houſes,
and in the morning couſening the novices,
he takes money for his temperance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And are not you troubled Menippus to dye?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: as it were of ſome crying from the earth.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: and his wife is taken by ſome women,
and there the Mother of Damaſias howling,
leads the lamentation of the women
But none weep for thee Menippus,
you lye moſt quietly of all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not you ſhall heare the Dogs anon
and the Crows whipping themſelves with their wings,
when they come together to bury me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But now we are come to land,

goe you to the ſeat
〈2 pages missing〉
juſtice,
I and the Ferryman will fetch others.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I wiſh you a good voyage Mercury,
and the torments they ſay are mighty.
for every mans life ſhall be laid open.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: AUdite quomodo ſe res habeant veſtrae,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Quid igitur facto opus eſt, ut tutò navigemus?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: ſuperflua haec omnia in littore relinquentes,
vix enim etiam ſic capiat vos navigium.
Tibi igitur ô Mercuri curae erit,

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: cujus oſculum duobus talentis emptum erat.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Sed diadema permitte me habere & veſtem.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Tu vero craſſus & carnoſus, quis es?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ecce tibi nudus, ut vides verè ſum,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: te civitas declaravit vindicem pro meritis ſcilicet,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: quòd ſi rebus his omnibus ingrediaris,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sed hanc barbā deponat, ô Mercuri,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Menippus, accipiens nauticam ſecurim, abſcindet illam,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Non Mercuri: ſed ſerrā mihi trade,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Maximè, nam has
ſuper frontem etiam attollit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Unum adhuc graviſſimum habet ſub alâ.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: quae multùm in vita fuit illi utilis.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Et tu igitur, ô Menippe, depone libertatem,

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Quia non amplius tam opiparas coenas habebit,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Et tu ô Menippe non gravatè fers quòd mortuus ſis?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Te autem nullus ô Menippe deflet,
